docs.lead_paragraph: Several consumer-focused stories appear today in various sections of The New York Times and online. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: For Thanksgiving Day, we sample reader comments posted Wednesday on the ''More and Spiritual Considerations'' topic page of the Health Care Conversations section of The New York Times Web site: nytimes.com/healthcareconversations. I believe strongly that health care for every American (actually for every person, but right now all we can do is deal with America) is a moral right. It is a sin, A SIN, that people in this country go to bed hungry, without a place to sleep and millions do not have minimal health care. FLAPROF, ST.. PETERSBURG, FLA.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has offered up an interesting explanation for his vote to move forward with debate of major health care legislation: he stopped his fellow Democrats from playing parliamentary hardball that he said would have led to a fast-tracked bill and ''sidelined'' centrists like himself. In an op-ed article in The Omaha World-Herald, Mr. Nelson suggested that if he had not agreed last Saturday to start formal debate on the health care bill, Senate Democratic leaders would have employed a tactic known as reconciliation to pass the legislation with a simple majority of 51 votes.

headline.main: A 'Yes' Vote For a Debate Is Explained

docs.abstract: Sen Ben Nelson, in op-ed article in Omaha World-Herald, offers explanation for his vote to move forward with debate of major health care legislation; says his vote stopped fellow Democrats from using parliamentary tactics that would have led to fast-tracked bill and sidelined centrists such as himself (M)

headline.main: Q&A: Insurance for a Long-Distance Backpacker

docs.abstract: "I'm about to go on a round-the-world backpacking trip for the next 6 to 12 months. My question is whether or not I need a separate travel health insurance plan."

docs.lead_paragraph: At the bankruptcy court in Nashville, lawyers provided a spectrum of estimates for the share of cases in Middle Tennessee where medical debt was decisive, from 15 percent to 50 percent. But many said they felt the number had been growing.
